unnormalised: The construction of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link extension is facing delays, primarily due to discrepancies in unit conversions. The initial plan, drafted in imperial units, specified a steel requirement of 500 tons for the main support pillars. However, the local suppliers operate primarily with the metric system.
normalised: The construction of the Bandra-Worli Sea Link extension is facing delays, primarily due to discrepancies in unit conversions. The initial plan, drafted in imperial units, specified a steel requirement of five hundred tons for the main support pillars. However, the local suppliers operate primarily with the metric system.

unnormalised: This led to confusion, with some estimates converting the 500 tons to 453.592 tonnes, while others rounded it to 454 tonnes. This discrepancy, though seemingly small, resulted in a miscalculation of nearly 0.4%, causing a shortage of approx. 2 tonnes of steel. The project managers have now mandated the use of SI units, specifically kilograms (kg) and meters (m), for all future material orders.
normalised: This led to confusion, with some estimates converting the five hundred tons to four hundred fifty three point five nine two tonnes, while others rounded it to four hundred fifty four tonnes. This discrepancy, though seemingly small, resulted in a miscalculation of nearly zero point four percent, causing a shortage of approximately two tonnes of steel. The project managers have now mandated the use of S-I units, specifically kilograms (k-g) and meters (m), for all future material orders.

unnormalised: Experts recommend using standardized conversion tools and adhering to strict unit consistency throughout the planning and execution phases. The Sea Link extension is now expected to be completed by 12/2024, a 3-month delay from the original projection, with a cost overrun of Rs. 20 crore, partially attributed to the reordering of materials.
normalised: Experts recommend using standardized conversion tools and adhering to strict unit consistency throughout the planning and execution phases. The Sea Link extension is now expected to be completed by december two thousand and twenty four, a three month delay from the original projection, with a cost overrun of rupee twenty crore, partially attributed to the reordering of materials.
